title: At 17 years old, do you think like an adult? - Quora

response.answer_text: I don’t believe that they do. This will all be generalisation of course but at 17 most people don’t have many responsibilities. Most don’t even wash up their own coffee cup, let alone have to worry about things like paying rent. They don’t have to take care of anyone but themselves, worry about putting food on the table, paying for clothes, TV, internet, gas, electric, cars and a myriad other such things. At 17, the focus is on themselves. They rarely notice the sheer amount of effort the adults around them have to put in to simply allow them and their loved ones to get through the day. For a 17 year old, failing a math test is a disaster. For an adult, a disaster is when your family has no food to eat and nowhere to live. As I said at the start of this answer. There will be exceptions. Young single mothers and fathers for example but for most 17 year olds. They don’t yet think like adults because they don’t yet have adult worries and responsibilities.

Some do. At 17, I had already graduated high school, had two and a half years of part-time work experience under my belt and had created my escape plan which was implemented at age 18. By 19, I was a store manager for a national electronics retail chain and attending college on the company’s tuition reimbursement program. I had to think like an adult. I had P&L responsibility for my unit and had employees who needed their paychecks - which depended on me running a profit.

Some 17 year olds do and some dont. It depends on who they are as a person. At 17 you DO have to see them as adults and treating them as such will ensure that they will go out into the real world with realistic expectations. Sometimes 17 year olds just want to have fun and not take any responsibility, and they havent experienced enough of the world yet to have the initiative either, so a teen like that would need to slowly be introduced to the adult world. At that age i was already wanting to get a job and a car. I wanted my own money so that i could go out and have fun since i came from a poor background. That was my only option if i wanted things i liked since my mother couldnt provide that. Seeing as how when youre an adult you have to work ANYWAY. What better time to start then the present.

No. You see, theres a button called adult thought in the back of your head and the second you turn 18 it turns on, so you are literally a child one day and an adult the next day. Well,at least thats what some really strange arguments seem to want you to think. Yet, really age maturity is a spectrum. At 18, you aren't much more mature than at 17. An 18 year old and a 17 year old are no more different than a 16 and 17 year old.

That depends on what you consider thinking like an adult. What does that entail? Having responsibilities like a job or a car payment, or a serious relationship? Developmentally a 17-year-old is not fully mature, but mentally they may exceed their physical age by any number of years. It really depends on the individual and their circumstances.

Absolutely not. Your brain won’t be fully developed until you are in your twenties. Between the ages of 17 and 25 you will undergo major personality changes. Then again, in this society there are so many Peter Pans who want to be kids forever, I often wonder if there are any adults left in the sense in which the word was used when I was growing up.

No. Specifically, the part of your brain that is able to do long-term planning is still development. As mentioned by Robert Martin Pollack, this will take another five or so years. What this means is, a 17 year old will make decisions that tend to leave out consideration of what may happen in the mid- to long-future. So, getting a job is good because it will give you money on Tuesday, rather than, getting a job is good because you can build a financial base that will allow you to get your own apartment in a year.

I can’t speak for anyone else, but at 17 years old, I most certainly did NOT think like an adult. Somewhat in my defense, an adolescent’s brain and mind does not fully mature for some years, and stabilizes somewhat in the late 20’s, depending on the person and environment.

I am 16 I think like an old man. I have lived a very terrible childhood I am still struggling withe life. I have no parents no family. That is why I am wise and think like an old man.everyone thinks at a different level depending on how they have grown up.
No 17 year olds think like an adult. They do not have the maturity. However, there are many adults who think like 17 year olds.
